title: Sound of Barra
text:
The Sound of Barra is a large ocean inlet or <a href="sound">sound</a> situated to the north of the <a href="island">isle</a> of <a href="Barra">Barra</a> and to the south of <a href="South%20Uist">South Uist</a> in the <a href="Outer%20Hebrides">Outer Hebrides</a> in <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. Since 2014 it has been designated as a <a href="Special%20Area%20of%20Conservation">Special Area of Conservation</a> (SAC). The Sound of Barra is composed of 98.91% marine and inlet areas, 1.07% mudflats and other semi-submerged areas and 0.02% sea cliffs and <a href="islets">islets</a>. There are ten islands in the sound, with only <a href="Eriskay">Eriskay</a> still being inhabited:
There is a ferry service across the sound from <a href="Ardmore%2C%20Barra">Ardmore</a> () on Barra to <a href="Ceann%20a%27%20Gh%C3%A0raidh">Ceann a' Ghàraidh</a> on the island of <a href="Eriskay">Eriskay</a>.
In 2000 it was proposed that the Sound of Barra should become a SAC. A 12-week consultation process was undertaken by <a href="NatureScot">Scottish Natural Heritage</a> (SNH) on behalf of the <a href="Scottish%20Government">Scottish Government</a> in the autumn of 2011 with two public meetings held in <a href="Castlebay">Castlebay</a> on <a href="Barra">Barra</a> and on <a href="Eriskay">Eriskay</a> as well as inviting submissions by letter and e-mail. SAC status was confirmed on 3 December 2014. The primary reasons for its status as a SAC are the benefits to <a href="marine%20conservation">marine conservation</a> of its sandbanks and reefs with their diverse <a href="flora">flora</a> and including <a href="maerl">maerl</a> and other <a href="red%20algae">red algae</a>, <a href="kelp">kelp</a> communities and <a href="fauna">fauna</a> such as <a href="barnacles">barnacles</a> and <a href="mussels">mussels</a> and the presence of <a href="harbour%20seals">harbour seals</a> also being a qualifying feature.
